title: Google takes bet on an Alpha future
text:
Google takes bet on an Alpha future Richard Waters in San Francisco ©AFP 
It’s official: Google has been reborn. 
The reinvention of the internet giant as tech holding company Alphabet, announced in August , caused barely a ripple when it officially took place on Friday. More Snapchat to launch sponsored selfies 
Google said the company’s new legal form and name change would take effect after the close of business, but that this was a legal formality with no immediate outward effects. 
The Alphabet switch is part of an attempt by co-founder and chief executive Larry Page to transcend what he believes are inevitable limits on growth that hold back normal companies. 
Speaking to the FT last year , Mr Page expressed frustration with the way all big companies hit a ceiling: “The biggest companies are all within an order of magnitude of the same size, certainly in market cap,” he said. 
He put the limitation down to the corporate arrangements that led to so many decisions ending up on the chief executive’s desk, creating a bottleneck that prevents them taking on as many new ideas as they would like. “It’s limited a lot of companies and maybe why they get to a certain size and maybe not get much bigger,” he said. 
The Alphabet arrangement is intended to overcome this hurdle — and enable Google to keep growing indefinitely, potentially making it the first trillion-dollar company — by handing most of the decisions to the heads of semi-autonomous business units. Outwardly, however, much will remain the same . 
The company said that, now the new legal form was in place, it would start to carve out its different divisions into wholly owned subsidiaries, including the Google internet business, the source of almost all its income. These include “smart city” venture Sidewalk Labs; “smart home” company Nest ; biotech arm Calico; and Google Life Sciences. Google Ventures, Google Capital and the Google X research labs will also become subsidiaries. 
When the stock market opens on Monday, the old Google will have been replaced by the new Alphabet — though its two classes of publicly traded shares will continue under their old ticker symbols, GOOG and GOOGL. 
The corporate reinvention will be accompanied by a small degree of extra financial transparency. Google has said that from January it will report results under two business segments, one representing its internet business and the other containing all its other operations. Investors have pushed for years for more information about how much of the huge profits from its search business Google has been ploughing back into its “moonshot” projects, such as driverless cars and Project Loon, a plan to bring internet access to remote regions by circling the earth with high-altitude balloons. 
“This will be a formality,” a spokesperson said of Friday’s legal switch. “There will be no change to any day-to-day operations.” Copyright The Financial Times Limited 2015. You may share using our article tools. Please don't cut articles from FT.com and redistribute by email or post to the web.
